narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I read foundational texts on Zen theory and Zen practice, and we discussed the essential tensions that have shaped Zen throughout history. Specifically, I learned to put religious practices and literature into dialogue and to analyze important questions about religions.
Reading primary texts and thinking critically about them, thinking critically about how my associations with Zen Buddhism and Western cultures

The student gave a "shout"

But what skills and insights? Can you name them?

Watch out. I have a fly whisk. 

(These are all good things, take the class to learn more. Beware the Zen Master).
I gained a deeper understanding of Buddhism and ways to approach thinking about religion in a critical way.
I gained an in depth overview of Zen Buddhism.
This course changed the way I thought not only about religion, but Eastern culture as a whole. It also challenged me to question Western notions about life, death, and everything they entail.

I learned that there is much to be taken away from cultures and ways of life that are very far away from yours. Through taking this course, my understanding of Zen life has helped me in my everyday life, being able to apply some of the principles to help better myself.

I developed the ability to write analytically and succinctly, a deeper knowledge of Zen Buddhism and its influences in modern culture, and a greater willingness to discuss with peers about the content with clarity.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The weekly seminar format was a welcome change of pace from other courses I had taken, and Professor Greene did an excellent job leading the discussions in a way that was inclusive to everyone's ideas. I would've loved -- actually -- if signing up for a  15-minute office hours session was mandatory around the 1/3 semester mark, and we had a chance to explore our ideas for essays earlier on, and to talk about the interesting / confusing aspects of Zen.

Strengths: Interesting subject, good structure to the course and class, good discussions, good ordering of topics. Weaknesses: readings were unnecessarily long at times, would have liked to talk more about Zen in the west and modern Zen, essay feedback didn't give specific things to improve on
I really enjoyed the level of reading, the weekly papers, and the class discussions. I think the course might have benefitted from a bit more direction at times.

Strength: well-organized in terms of overall structure, engaging and knowledgable professor
Weaknesses: I wish I'd gotten to know the other students more

A lot of the information presented in this course is difficult to understand at first, and thorough examination of it often leads to more confusion. Unfortunately, the course was presented in such a way that it wasn't always led by the professor, instead leaving confused students discussing ideas that don't make sense, leading to further confusion.

Strengths: Topics are interesting, valuable readings
Weakness: spend more time on actual Zen

The organization of the content was very effective. The readings for each week were interesting and different from the last week and gave a substantial introduction to the topic. 

Discussion could be improved significantly. Often it became difficult to have a good conversation in class. I think this is partially due to the number of students in the class. It seemed a bit too large for discussion to flow properly. Also, I would have preferred for Professor Greene to give more feedback on the weekly essays.
This course was very well designed and I truly enjoyed writing the weekly essays that corresponded with the readings. One weakness, perhaps, was the lack of a course packet.

The strengths of this course come through the required texts that are assigned every week. The order in which we read each text created a solid  understanding of the history of Zen so that we could make our own arguments about the later texts coming into more modern times. I also enjoyed the discussions as the class had fascinating interpretations and insights to the readings.

This was one of my favorite classes at Yale. It has made me reflect on the way I live my life and how it impacts other people around me on a deeper level. I think the only thing I would improve about this course is to decrease the seminar size so that everyone gets a chance to speak about their thoughts. Otherwise, this is an amazing course!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would strongly recommend this course to students interested in Zen. It might be more difficult for people, actually, with strong pre-conceptions about Zen who aren't willing to adjust their framework, but on the whole, I found the class intellectually rewarding and spiritually satisfying. A fun point: when your friends ask: "So what is Zen all about?" you will not be able to answer them succinctly.

I would recommend this course to another student but warn them that the readings are lengthy and class felt a bit slow on Friday afternoons at times. Most of the discussions were philosophical and made me think about things in a new way, but some of the topics felt repetitive.

Take this course and you will not regret it. This is one of the only once-weekly classes I've taken where I felt truly engaged by the material and class structure. It was a beautiful part of my Fridays and I learned a lot--you will too!
Yes, great intro religious studies course!
If the course were changed to either be a lecture or more professor-led, I would absolutely recommend this course to others. As it stands now, however, I would not.
yes. readings were very interesting and professor greene gives a good introduction to zen buddhism. The weekly essays force you to think about what you're reading critically.
Certainly! Professor Greene is very engaging and approachable.
If you are interested in learning about a completely different way of life and how it came into such established tradition, take this course.
Yes, of course! This course will certainly make you think outside of the box and philosophically about religions and your own life!
